summary: This chapter discusses the formation of habits, starting with Edward Thorndike's experiment with cats in puzzle boxes, which demonstrated how behaviors followed by satisfying consequences are more likely to be repeated. A habit is defined as a behavior that has been repeated enough times to become automatic, beginning with trial and error. The brain automates solutions to problems, decreasing activity as habits form, turning them into mental shortcuts. Habits free up mental capacity, allowing focus on other tasks, and create freedom by handling fundamental tasks efficiently. The process of building a habit involves four steps: cue, craving, response, and reward, which form a neurological feedback loop. The cue triggers a craving, which motivates a response, leading to a reward that satisfies the craving and reinforces the association with the cue. These steps can be divided into problem (cue and craving) and solution (response and reward) phases, driven by the desire to solve problems. The chapter introduces the Four Laws of Behavior Change: cue (make it obvious), craving (make it attractive), response (make it easy), and reward (make it satisfying), which can be inverted to break bad habits. The ultimate purpose of habits is to solve problems efficiently, and any habit can be broken down into the cue, craving, response, and reward feedback loop.

evidence.verbatim_text: [01:02:24,732,01:02:34,379] In 1898, a psychologist named Edward Thorndike conducted an experiment that would lay the foundation for our understanding of how habits form and the rules that guide our behavior.
[01:02:35,620,01:02:40,204] Thorndike was interested in studying the behavior of animals, and he started by working with cats.
[01:02:41,104,01:02:44,086] He would place each cat inside a device known as a puzzle box.
[01:03:24,459,01:03:26,980] In the beginning, the animals moved around the box at random.
[01:03:32,538,01:03:39,147] Gradually, each cat learned to associate the action of pressing the lever with the reward of escaping the box and getting to the food.
[01:03:40,429,01:03:46,257] After 20 to 30 trials, this behavior became so automatic and habitual that the cat could escape within a few seconds.

[01:04:36,444,01:04:47,587] From his studies, Thorndike described the learning process by stating, behaviors followed by satisfying consequences tend to be repeated, and those that produce unpleasant consequences are less likely to be repeated.
[01:05:04,274,01:05:07,936] A habit is a behavior that has been repeated enough times to become automatic.
[01:05:08,797,01:05:11,618] The process of habit formation begins with trial and error.
[01:05:12,519,01:05:17,821] Whenever you encounter a new situation in life, your brain has to make a decision. How do I respond to this?
[01:05:39,216,01:05:41,797] The brain is busy learning the most effective course of action.
[01:06:19,599,01:06:25,220] With practice, the useless movements fade away and the useful actions get reinforced. That's a habit forming.
[01:06:31,806,01:06:36,910] Your habits are just a series of automatic solutions that solve the problems and stresses you face regularly.
[01:06:46,217,01:06:49,639] As habits are created, the level of activity in the brain decreases.
[01:07:27,523,01:07:29,564] Habits are mental shortcuts learned from experience.
[01:07:47,517,01:07:51,739] Habit formation is incredibly useful because the conscious mind is the bottleneck of the brain.
[01:08:11,010,01:08:16,993] Habits reduce cognitive load and free up mental capacity so you can allocate your attention to other tasks.
[01:08:41,505,01:08:46,808] In reality, the two complement each other. Habits do not restrict freedom. They create it.
[01:09:35,486,01:09:41,431] The science of how habits work. The process of building a habit can be divided into four simple steps.
[01:09:42,432,01:09:50,358] Cue, craving, response, and reward. Readers of The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg will recognize these terms.
[01:10:09,235,01:10:15,078] This four-step pattern is the backbone of every habit, and your brain runs through these steps in the same order each time.
[01:10:16,219,01:10:20,361] First, there's the cue. The cue triggers your brain to initiate a behavior.
[01:11:07,350,01:11:11,033] Cravings are the second step, and they are the motivational force behind every habit.
[01:12:15,759,01:12:20,282] The response is the actual habit you perform, which can take the form of a thought or an action.
[01:12:45,404,01:12:50,497] Finally, the response delivers a reward.  Rewards are the end goal of every habit.
[01:13:34,462,01:13:40,748] Second, rewards teach us which actions are worth remembering in the future. Your brain is a reward detector.
[01:14:00,832,01:14:04,913] If a behavior is insufficient in any of these four stages, it will not become a habit.
[01:14:36,694,01:14:46,758] In summary, the cue triggers a craving, which motivates a response, which provides a reward, which satisfies that craving, and ultimately becomes associated with the cue.
[01:15:34,172,01:15:39,415] The problem phase includes the cue and the craving, and it is when you realize that something needs to change.
[01:15:40,115,01:15:46,459] The solution phase includes the response and the reward, and it is when you take action and achieve the change you desire.
[01:15:47,988,01:15:50,490] All behavior is driven by the desire to solve a problem.
[01:17:52,119,01:17:59,781] In the following chapters, we will see time and again how the four stages of cue, craving, response, and reward influence nearly everything we do each day.
[01:18:09,508,01:18:16,973] I refer to this framework as the Four Laws of Behavior Change, and it provides a simple set of rules for creating good habits and breaking bad ones.

[01:18:35,154,01:18:42,279] Here's how you can use the four laws to create a good habit. Q, the first law, make it obvious.
Craving, the second law, make it attractive. Response, the third law, make it easy.
[01:18:43,019,01:18:49,745] Reward, the fourth law, make it satisfying. And we can invert these laws to learn how to break a bad habit.
[01:20:34,227,01:20:40,389] The ultimate purpose of habits is to solve the problems of life with as little energy and effort as possible.
[01:20:41,530,01:20:47,853] Any habit can be broken down into a feedback loop that involves four steps, cue, craving, response, and reward.
